title: During a chapter 7 or 13 bankruptcy can you be forced to stop contributing to a company match 401k to satisfy creditors?
question: The company matches 100% of the first 5% of wages the employee contributes in this case. If retirement is 5-10 years away this would be tough.
answers: The law is unclear on the issue allowance for contributions to a 401k. Mandatory retirement contributions are deductible from gross income under the Means Test when calculating disposable income. Voluntary contributions are not deductible for the purpose of the Means Test. However, when looking at the a debtor's overall financial situation a voluntary deduction for 401k may be allowed as a valid expense on the Debtor's Income and/or expense schedules (I and J). You note that retirement is 5-10 years away for you. The court may allow a retirement contribution of 5% if you can show that it is resaonable and necessary for your support in retirement. If you have a limited amount of funds in your retirement account and you plan on retiring in 10 years a contribution of 5% may be deemed reasonable and necessary for your support. If however you are 25 years away from retirement and you already have a substantial sum in your retirement account, a voluntary contribution of 5% may not be reasonable and necessary for your support in retirement. You should go over the entire set of facts regarding your retirement funds and contributions with your lawyer to determine what the court may decide in allowing you continue to make a 5% voluntary contribution to your retiement. It has been my experience that the Bankruptcy Courts in California are receptive to allowing a contribution in the 5% range.

That's a great question. The short answer is no. No one is going to force you to reduce or eliminate making voluntary contributions to a qualified retirement account. You don't specify how much you are contributing or wish to contribute. In my experience, trustees will view voluntary contributions to retirement accounts in the range of 3 - 6% as reasonable. Trustees don't view such payroll deductions in a vaccum, however. Trustees and courts also take into considerations such variables as a Debtor's age and the amount of funds already available in existing retirement accounts. Certainly, it can be argued that contributing 5% when your employer will match dollar for dollar is a very reasonable (and prudent) investment choice. A voluntary contribution of 10 - 15% may not seem so reasonable to a chapter 7 or 13 trustee, however. In my opinion, the amount contributed to a retirement account will be a bigger issue in a chapter 13 case as compared to a chapter 7 case. Expenses and payroll deductions tend to be more heavily scrutinized in chapter 13 cases. The good news is that in chapter 13, reasonable voluntary retirement contributions may act to reduce the amount of money you will be obligated to pay your unsecured creditors. Reasonable contributions are not viewed disfavorably by the trustees or courts, especially if you have a proven track record of making such contributions and you aren't merely trying to game the system.

The answer to this question may be different in different parts of the US. In Nevada, you cannot continue to make voluntary contributions to your retirement and use these contributions to reduce the amount you pay to your bankruptcy trustee each month in a Chapter 13. And while you could continue to contribute to your retirement even after filing Chapter 13, you would have to reduce some other necessary expenses to be able to afford to do this.

Gosh, this is confusing! What does this mean!

In a Chapter 7, you should show that you have less than $168/month available to pay debts. You can't subtract your 401K or other voluntary retirement contributions to come up with this number.

In Chapter 13, you also can't subtract your 401K or voluntarily retirement contributions from your budget. You must pay 100% of the money you have left over! But from a practical standpoint, if you can cut down on your necessary living expenses, such as gasoline, groceries, cell phone, recreation expenses, you might be able to continue these contributions.

Unfortunately, differences exist between the bankruptcy courts throughout the US & what applies in one court may not apply in your court.

Anyway, I hope this info helps. Good luck!
